channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Can a Tiny Territory in the South Pacific Power Tesla’s Ambitions?
item.description: Nickel is vital to electric car batteries, but extracting it is dirty and destructive. A plant with a turbulent history in New Caledonia is about to become an experiment in sustainable mining.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nickel mine processing plant in Prony, New Caledonia.

item.title: A Divided World United to Launch the James Webb Space Telescope
item.description: “I’ve always seen space as an area where we cooperate, through all the trying times,” said a professor who oversaw mission control for the global effort to launch a $10 billion telescope into space.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:description: The mirror of the James Webb Space Telescope in 2016. Its launch on Christmas was a reminder that international cooperation on grand-scale projects was still possible.

item.title: Ashraf Ghani, Former Afghan President, Says He Fled Nation to 'Save Kabul'
item.description: In his first interview since escaping Afghanistan as the Taliban advanced on the capital, Ashraf Ghani defended himself against charges that he abandoned his country in its hour of need.
item.dc:creator: Sharif Hassan
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashraf Ghani, then the president of Afghanistan, at a campaign rally in Kabul in 2019. He centralized power to such an extent that the entire system collapsed soon after his departure.

item.title: In 2021, We Were There: The Year’s 14 Most Popular Dispatches
item.description: Not even a pandemic, wars or autocrats could prevent our correspondents from seeking out secrets and surprises to share with readers. They sent dispatches from 40 countries on six continents.
item.dc:creator: Bryant Rousseau
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times

item.title: China Keeps 13 Million in Xi’an Under Strict Lockdown
item.description: The severe measures in Xi’an have prompted concern, as residents complain on social media of having trouble ordering food online.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:description: A sanitation worker swept a deserted road this week in Xi'an, in the northern Chinese province of Shaanxi.

item.title: Covid Live Updates: Incoming Mayor to Keep N.Y.C.’s Private-Sector Vaccine Mandate
item.description: The U.S. set a one-day record of nearly half a million cases, a staggering figure, although hospitalizations are not rising as fast. A study shows that a booster shot of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine provides strong protection against Omicron.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times

item.title: Spurred by Omicron, Europe Sets Covid Infection Records Every Day
item.description: The surge of cases is causing chaos as people scramble to obtain tests, businesses grapple with staff shortages and New Year’s festivities are thrown into question.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line formed at a Covid testing center in London on Wednesday, as Britain experienced a sharp rise in the number of cases, likely driven by the Omicron variant.

item.title: As the Kremlin Revises History, a Human Rights Champion Becomes a Casualty
item.description: The shuttering of Memorial, the country’s most prominent human rights organization, has saddened Russians who were personally touched by its work shining a light on the injustices of the Soviet past.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Police officers outside the Moscow City Court, where a hearing over the closure of Memorial’s Human Rights Center took place on Wednesday.

item.title: 11 Years After Trying to Kill Each Other, a Marine and a Talib Meet Again
item.description: A Times reporter who once served in the Marines returned to the site of a major battle in Afghanistan to see what’s changed since the Taliban took over — and to meet a commander he once fought.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, in red hat, interviewing Mullah Abdul Rahim Gulab, below the weapon in the window.

item.title: India Fears a Third Wave of Covid, Driven by Omicron
item.description: The health ministry recorded more than 13,000 new cases in a day, one of the highest daily totals since October.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: A health worker collects a swab sample of a passenger at a train station in New Delhi on Thursday.

item.title: Indonesia Accepts Stranded Refugee Boat After Vowing to Turn It Away
item.description: The boat was being towed ashore with more than 100 Rohingya refugees on board. Indonesia initially said it would turn the vessel away, but relented under pressure from rights groups.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: A wooden boat transporting Rohingya refugees was intercepted in the waters off Indonesia this week.

item.title: U.K. Plans Field Wards to Meet Omicron Surge
item.description: Unlike the “Nightingale hospitals” that went largely unused during the first virus wave, the new facilities are designed for patients needing less intensive treatment.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A temporary field hospital being erected on the grounds of St. George’s Hospital in London, on Thursday.

item.title: Making Sense of Covid Changes
item.description: What experts say about new C.D.C. rules and rising case numbers.
item.dc:creator: Tom Wright-Piersanti and Claire Moses
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Receiving an at-home test kit this week in Washington.

item.title: J. & J. Booster Protects Against Severe Omicron, Study Says
item.description: Two shots of the vaccine reduced the risk of hospitalization from the fast-spreading variant by 85 percent, a clinical trial found.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: Administering the Johnson & Johnson vaccine in Johannesburg. The shot is a mainstay of Covid public health efforts in Africa.

item.title: Años Viejos: Torching the Old Year to Toast the New One
item.description: In parts of Latin America, the traditional burning of rag dolls was used to symbolically banish the woes of the year gone by. Nowadays, it’s not uncommon to see TV hosts and ex-presidents going up in flames.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz
item.media:description: “Años viejos” for sale on a sidewalk in Guayaquil, Ecuador.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is found guilty.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: US District Court for the Southern District of New York/AFP via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ghislaine Maxwell, right, and Jeffrey Epstein in an undated photo that was used as evidence in Maxwell’s trial.

item.title: Biden and Putin Will Hold a Call on Ukraine
item.description: The Russian president requested Thursday’s call, which will be the second time in three weeks that the two leaders speak about tensions at the Ukrainian border.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Russian military exercises near Ukraine’s eastern border last week. American officials have continued to express concerns about the presence of Russian troops in the region.

item.title: World Junior Championship, a Showcase for Hockey’s Top Prospects, Is Canceled
item.description: The cancellation was an ominous sign for sports leagues, including the N.H.L. and the N.B.A., which have been struggling to maintain schedules.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Jason Franson/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rogers Place arena in Edmonton, Alberta, sat empty after the remainder of the IIHF World Junior Hockey Championship was canceled on Wednesday because of the spread of the coronavirus among players.

item.title: Testing Site in Connecticut Is Forced to Close After Gun Threat
item.description: Another location nearby also shut down after the crowd grew agitated.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Morris
item.media:credit: Amanda Morris for the New York Times
item.media:description: A Bristol, Conn., testing site was forced to shut down after a woman who said she was waiting in line threatened to shoot people.

item.title: 2022 Westminster Dog Show Postponed Amid Omicron Surge
item.description: The 2021 show was pushed to June and held outdoors because of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:description: The Westminster Kennel Club’s board of governors announced on Wednesday that it was postponing its 2022 dog show, which had been scheduled for late January.

item.title: Eric Adams to Be Sworn In on New Year's Eve in Times Square
item.description: The incoming mayor has made a point of reveling in New York’s nightlife, something that he has cast as boosterism for the city’s struggling club and restaurant scene.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein
item.media:description: Eric Adams will be sworn in by the city clerk, using Mr. Adams’s family Bible.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Myanmar’s Crisis
item.description: Refugees in limbo and danger for those who stay.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Biak Tling was forced to flee Myanmar for India, along with his family.

item.title: Cincinnati Declares State of Emergency Amid Fire Department Staffing Shortages
item.description: Mayor John Cranley called the challenges a “public danger” that would undermine the city’s ability to respond to fire emergencies.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Sam Greene/The Cincinnati Enquirer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mayor John Cranley of Cincinnati said the fire department staffing challenges were a “public danger.”

item.title: Cases surge in Argentina, raising questions about what is to come in South America.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing center in Buenos Aires last week.

item.title: Fearing a mistrial because of Omicron’s spread, a judge extends jury’s hours in Ghislaine Maxwell trial.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser and Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Thurgood Marshall United States Courthouse in lower Manhattan on Wednesday as jury deliberations continue in the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

item.title: Five Smithsonian Museums Close Amid Omicron Staff Shortages
item.description: The museums will temporarily close as the Smithsonian routes staff to other outposts.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Jared Soares for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Smithsonian National Museum of African Art in Washington is among four museums closing through Sunday because of the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: A Colorado slaughterhouse has upped vaccinations, but workers still feel fear, and anger.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:description: San Twin with her son, Felix, who was born as her own mother was hospitalized with a fatal case of Covid.

item.title: Israel's Avian Flu Outbreak Has Killed Thousands of Cranes
item.description: Thousands of migratory cranes have died and more than half a million chickens have been culled as the country tries to contain a deadly bird virus.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A dead crane, foreground, at the Hula Nature Reserve in northern Israel last week.

item.title: A Movement to Unify the French Left Might Be Its Last Chance for the Elections
item.description: A citizens’ initiative is pressuring the fragmented force to set parties’ interests aside and join together for next year’s presidential race.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Léontine Gallois
item.media:description: Arnaud Montebourg, a former minister in the Socialist government of François Hollande who is now running for president, in Frangy-en-Bresse, France, in September for an annual party meeting.

item.title: Stay or Go? For Myanmar’s Latest Wave of Refugees, There’s No Good Choice.
item.description: Hundreds of thousands who fled deadly unrest at home confront an uncertain future abroad. Yet for many who remained, conditions are dire.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Biak Tling and Tial Hoi Chin in Farkawn, India, in December with their 18-month-old twins, Bawi Thwang Cung and Bawi Lian Cung. They are among the hundreds of thousands who have fled Myanmar in fear of their lives.

item.title: Britons seeking Covid tests find themselves out of luck across most of the U.K.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line for vaccinations in London on Wednesday. Britain is experiencing a sharp rise in the number of Covid cases, and tests of all kinds are getting hard to come by.

item.title: Air filters and outdoor spaces: Office costs rise as workers return.
item.dc:creator: Julie Weed
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: A building engineer installing air filters in a Seattle office building this month.

item.title: Omicron tears across Europe, leaving tests and patience in short supply.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Picking up lateral flow coronavirus test kits on Tuesday at a pharmacy in Madrid.

item.title: Saudi Arabia will require booster shots to enter many public places.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Checking for vaccine certificates or a negative coronavirus test in Riyadh, in June.

item.title: The Year’s Most Read
item.description: The stories you read, clicked and spent the most time with.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning

item.title: Singapore charges a man accused of lending out his vaccination record, and other international news.
item.description: A 65-year-old used the records of a 37-year-old to pretend he had been fully vaccinated, court indictments said.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Muktita Suhartono and Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Boat Quay riverside in Singapore. Daily coronavirus cases in Singapore have declined to fewer than 500 in the past two weeks from more than 3,000 in late October.

item.title: Two Georgia Republicans have racked up $100,000 in fines for defying a mask mandate in Congress.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Andrew Clyde called the fines “deeply troubling,” and Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene said the mandate was “tyrannical.”

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Omicron marches on.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A cinema near Leicester Square advertises the need for a covid pass to enter on Tuesday, in London.

item.title: Keri Hulme, New Zealand’s First Booker Prize Winner, Dies at 74
item.description: The power Ms. Hulme drew from her Maori heritage shone through in her work, especially in “The Bone People,” which won the literary prize in 1985.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Bernard Weil/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Keri Hulme’s debut novel, “The Bone People,” was inspired by a series of dreams, took 17 years to write and was rejected by multiple publishers.

item.title: U.S. Coronavirus Cases Set New Records
item.description: As a third year of the pandemic loomed, the seven-day average of U.S. cases topped 267,000 on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Ron DePasquale
item.media:description: Health care workers administered tests on Tuesday in Stamford, Conn. Americans have rushed to get tested as the Omicron variant spreads.

item.title: Hong Kong Police Raid Stand News and Arrest Staff
item.description: Those arrested, including current and former senior staff members of Stand News, were accused of conspiring to publish seditious material. The news site announced it would shut down immediately.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: Will Shortened Isolation Periods Without Testing Spread the Virus?
item.description: Without rapid testing, some experts fear new U.S. guidelines may mean infected people leave isolation while still contagious. The C.D.C. director said masking was a better option.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A traveler arrived at the Los Angeles International Airport on Tuesday, where staff shortages prompted flight cancellations that disrupted holiday travel. “To me, this feels honestly more about economics than about the science,” one health expert said of the C.D.C.’s new guidance.

item.title: Some Infected Quebec Health Care Workers can Continue Working
item.description: All essential workers in the province, including those who work in medicine, will be subject to the new rules.
item.dc:creator: Todd Gregory
item.media:description: Vivien Murphy, 9, received a shot last month at a vaccination clinic in Montreal, the largest city in Quebec.

item.title: Omicron Variant May Help Beat Delta, Study Suggests
item.description: In the lab, antibodies produced during an Omicron infection protected against Delta. If Omicron dominates in the real world, that could lead to a less dire future.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: The Africa Health Research Institute in Durban, South Africa, where researchers performed a study of 13 blood samples from people who were vaccinated or had recovered from Covid, and mixed them with different variants.

item.title: U.S. and Russia Agree to Talks Amid Growing Tensions Over Ukraine
item.description: The Biden administration has not said who will lead the U.S. delegation next month as Russian officials demand commitments from NATO.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Russian troops near Ukraine this month. The threat of a possible invasion of Ukraine is critical leverage for Moscow.

item.title: Brazil Flooding Kills at Least 20 and Displaces Thousands
item.description: In northeast Brazil, local officials say they have never before seen flooding on this scale. Tens of thousands were forced to flee their homes.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.media:description: Vitoria Rocha, 81, by the remains of her home in Itambé, in Bahia State, on Tuesday.

item.title: C.D.C. Study Suggests Omicron's Incubation Period Is Just 3 Days
item.description: A case study of one infected household observed that it may take as little as three days for people to become contagious, compared with four to six days with earlier versions of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A computer-generated image of multiple copies of the Omicron variant.

item.title: Hugh Jackman Announces He Has Covid-19
item.description: The show joins other productions that have been suspended, including the Temptations musical “Ain’t Too Proud,” which will close for good on Jan. 16.
item.dc:creator: Laura Zornosa
item.media:description: “The Music Man” will resume performances on Sunday, and Jackman will return to the show on Jan. 6.

item.title: Omicron Prompts New Year’s Eve Cancellations
item.description: No big parties in Paris, Rome, Tokyo and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Striking a pose with the 2022 sign in Times Square this month.

item.title: Fears of Omicron’s Rapid Spread Are Tempered by Signs of Milder Illness
item.description: “We can’t stop it,” Israel’s prime minister said of the Omicron variant, but that warning was blunted by early signs of potentially less-severe illness than with earlier coronavirus iterations.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Megan Specia
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A market along the Spree River in Berlin was locked on Monday as Germany put in place new restrictions to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Britain’s Crossbow Rules in the Cross Hairs After Windsor Castle Breach
item.description: Britain’s Home Office said it was “considering options to strengthen controls” on the weapons, part of a continuing review, after a man was arrested in castle grounds with one.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: A police officer standing guard at Windsor Castle on Christmas. The queen spent the holiday there.

item.title: Born and Raised in Pakistan, but Living in Legal Limbo
item.description: Pakistan has refused to grant the children of Afghan refugees full rights as citizens. A lack of identification documents limits their livelihoods and puts them at risk of deportation.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Saiyna Bashir
item.media:description: Madad Ali, a young Afghan who works in software development in Pakistan, says he goes to the beach “to overcome depression.”

item.title: Doctors Strike Over Understaffing Disrupts Delhi Hospitals
item.description: While the country’s overall case count remains low, daily infections in the capital region have risen by more than 300 percent over the past two weeks.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: A protest over staffing shortages at state-run hospitals in New Delhi called by a doctors’ association on Tuesday.

item.title: Chile Writes Its Constitution, Confronting Climate Change Head On
item.description: Chile has lots of lithium, which is essential to the world’s transition to green energy. But anger over powerful mining interests, a water crisis and inequality has driven Chile to rethink how it defines itself.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Marcos Zegers
item.category: Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile SA

item.title: India Cuts Off Foreign Funding of Mother Teresa’s Charity
item.description: The move is part of a tightening of rules on organizations financed by donations from abroad and comes amid a rise in attacks on religious minorities.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: Nuns from the Missionaries of Charity praying under a banner of Mother Teresa in Kolkata, India, in August.

item.title: An Australian teenager who partied while positive is charged with ignoring health orders.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang, Saif Hasnat and John Yoon
item.media:description: Waiting in line to take P.C.R. tests in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday.
